title: Socialite Hitchcock was 'hypoglycaemic'
text:
By AAP 
Sydney socialite Shari-Lea Hitchcock, who allegedly assaulted a police officer and lashed out at a Good Samaritan, has blamed her behaviour on a hypoglycemic episode. 
Hitchcock, 47, was charged with resisting arrest, assaulting an officer and common assault after the ugly incident last March. 
Police allege she appeared intoxicated and became aggressive towards a woman who tried to help her across the road in peak-hour traffic on Oxford Street, Woollahra, in Sydney's east. 
She was further accused of putting up a "short struggle", biting and kicking a female constable in the process. 
In Sydney's Waverley Local Court on Tuesday, her lawyer Greg James said Hitchcock appeared disoriented when she tried to get into a taxi, and the passer-by persuaded the driver not to take her. 
Mr James submitted a doctor's report stating his client was suffering from a hypoglycemic episode at the time. 
"That condition seems to be generated by her weight, the work that she'd been doing (and) the limited amount of food she'd ingested over the previous 24 hours," he said. 
Hitchcock was restrained by the passer-by, Mr James said. 
"When the police appear and seek to take her into custody, she reacts on a belief ... that she is being unlawfully detained and increasingly reacts in a way that is increasingly irrational," he told the court. 
Hitchcock had suffered from the same condition previously and experienced amnesia and blackouts from working too hard, Mr James added. 
On the day of the incident, the 47-year-old, the former long-time mistress of late billionaire Richard Pratt, had lunch and consumed two glasses of alcohol. 
Hitchcock's health concerns were first flagged in court last May. 
Section 32 of the Mental Health Act 1990 allows for criminal charges to be dismissed if a person agrees to comply with a treatment plan. 
Police prosecutor Stephen Dayeian resisted the application. 
The hearing, before magistrate Michael Barko, will resume on Tuesday afternoon with evidence from the author of the medical report. Â© AAP 2017
